Description:
In programming APIs (not in communication between hosts), requests a 
system-allocated (dynamic) port[5]

TCP Port Service Multiplexer (TCPMUX). Historic. Both TCP and UDP have been 
assigned to TCPMUX by IANA,[1] but by design only TCP is specified.[6]

Remote Job Entry[7] was historically using socket 5 in its old socket form, 
while MIB PIM has identified it as TCP/5[8] and IANA has assigned both TCP 
and UDP 5 to it.

Secure Shell (SSH),[10] secure logins, file transfers (scp, sftp) and port 
forwarding

Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP),[10][24] used for email routing 
between mail servers

TACACS Login Host protocol.[30] TACACS+, still in draft which is an 
improved but distinct version of TACACS, only uses TCP 49.[31]

Historically used for Interface Message Processor logical address 
management,[32] entry has been removed by IANA on 2013-05-25

Xerox Network Systems (XNS) Time Protocol. Despite this port being assigned 
by IANA, the service is meant to work on SPP (ancestor of IPX/SPX), instead 
of TCP/IP.[33]

Xerox Network Systems (XNS) Clearinghouse (Name Server). Despite this port 
being assigned by IANA, the service is meant to work on SPP (ancestor of 
IPX/SPX), instead of TCP/IP.[33]

Xerox Network Systems (XNS) Authentication Protocol. Despite this port 
being assigned by IANA, the service is meant to work on SPP (ancestor of 
IPX/SPX), instead of TCP/IP.[33]

Xerox Network Systems (XNS) Mail. Despite this port being assigned by IANA, 
the service is meant to work on SPP (ancestor of IPX/SPX), instead of 
TCP/IP.[33]

Historically assigned to the NIFTP-Based Mail protocol,[35] but was never 
documented in the related IEN.[36] The port number entry was removed from 
IANA's registry on 2017-05-18.[1]

Bootstrap Protocol (BOOTP) server;[10] also used by Dynamic Host 
Configuration Protocol (DHCP)

Bootstrap Protocol (BOOTP) client;[10] also used by Dynamic Host 
Configuration Protocol (DHCP)

QUIC, a transport protocol over UDP (still in draft as of April 2020[update]), 
using stream multiplexing, encryption by default with TLS, and currently 
supporting HTTP/2.[49] QUIC has been renamed to HTTP/3, which is currently 
an Internet Draft.
MIT ML Device, networking file system [50]
ISO Transport Service Access Point (TSAP) Class 0 protocol;[55][56]
Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine (DICOM; also port 11112)
IBM Systems Network Architecture (SNA) gateway access server

Open Network Computing Remote Procedure Call (*ONC RPC*, sometimes referred 
to as *Sun RPC*)

Ident, authentication service/identification protocol,[10][62] used by IRC 
servers to identify users

Authentication Service (auth), the predecessor to *identification protocol*. 
Used to determine a user's identity of a particular TCP connection.[63]

Network News Transfer Protocol (NNTP),[10] retrieval of newsgroup messages
[65][66]
Network Time Protocol (NTP), used for time synchronization[10]

Formerly Unisys Unitary Login, renamed by Unisys to NXEdit. Used by Unisys 
Programmer's Workbench for Clearpath MCP, an IDE for Unisys MCP software 
development

Microsoft EPMAP (End Point Mapper), also known as DCE/RPC Locator service,
[67] used to remotely manage services including DHCP server, DNS server and 
WINS. Also used by DCOM
NetBIOS Name Service, used for name registration and resolution[68][69]

Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP),[10] management of electronic mail 
messages on a server[70]

Simple Gateway Monitoring Protocol (SGMP), a protocol for remote inspection 
and alteration of gateway management information[72]

Distributed Mail System Protocol (*DMSP*, sometimes referred to as *Pcmail*)
[73][*importance?*]

Simple Network Management Protocol Trap (SNMPTRAP)[74][75][*citation needed*
]

X Display Manager Control Protocol (XDMCP), used for remote logins to an X 
Display Manager server[76][*self-published source*]

Border Gateway Protocol (BGP),[77] used to exchange routing and 
reachability information among autonomous systems (AS) on the Internet
Mac OS X Server Admin[10] (officially AppleShare IP Web administration[1])
Mapping of Airline Traffic over Internet Protocol (MATIP) type A
cloanto-net-1 (used by Cloanto Amiga Explorer and VMs)

securecast1, outgoing packets to NAI's SecureCast servers[81]As of 2000
[update]

Unidata LDM near real-time data distribution protocol[83][*self-published 
source*][84][*self-published source*]
Digital Equipment Corporation DECnet+ (Phase V) over TCP/IP (RFC1859)
NNSP, part of Network News Transfer Protocol

Quick UDP Internet Connections (QUIC), a transport protocol over UDP (still 
in draft as of July 2018[update]), using stream multiplexing, encryption by 
default with TLS, and currently supporting HTTP/2.[49]
Microsoft-DS (Directory Services) Active Directory,[85] Windows shares
URL Rendezvous Directory for SSM (Cisco protocol)[*importance?*]
tcpnethaspsrv, Aladdin Knowledge Systems Hasp services
GO-Global remote access and application publishing software

Internet Security Association and Key Management Protocol (ISAKMP) / Internet 
Key Exchange (IKE)[10]

Citadel, multiservice protocol for dedicated clients for the Citadel 
groupware system
FirstClass Protocol (FCP), used by FirstClass client/server groupware system

Remote Shell, used to execute non-interactive commands on a remote system 
(Remote Shell, rsh, remsh)

NetWare Core Protocol (NCP) is used for a variety things such as access to 
primary NetWare server resources, Time Synchronization, etc.

Legacy use of Internet Message Access Protocol over TLS/SSL (IMAPS), now in 
use at port 993.[88]
FileMaker 6.0 (and later) Web Sharing (HTTP Alternate, also see port 80)

HTTP RPC Ep Map, Remote procedure call over Hypertext Transfer Protocol, 
often used by Distributed Component Object Model services and Microsoft 
Exchange Server
Reliable Syslog Service — used for system logging

TUNNEL profile,[90] a protocol for BEEP peers to form an application layer 
tunnel

ASF Remote Management and Control Protocol (ASF-RMCP) & IPMI Remote 
Management Protocol
Common Unix Printing System (CUPS) administration console (extension to IPP)
Lightweight Directory Access Protocol over TLS/SSL (LDAPS)[10]

SupportSoft Nexus Remote Command (control/listening), a proxy gateway 
connecting remote control traffic
Label Distribution Protocol (LDP), a routing protocol used in MPLS networks

SupportSoft Nexus Remote Command (data), a proxy gateway connecting remote 
control traffic
Media Management System (MMS) Media Management Protocol (MMP)[93]

IBM RMC (Remote monitoring and Control) protocol, used by System p5 AIX 
Integrated Virtualization Manager (IVM)[94] and Hardware Management Console 
to connect managed logical partitions (LPAR) to enable dynamic partition 
reconfiguration
Mac OS X Server administration,[1] version 10.4 and earlier[10]
airserv-ng, aircrack-ng's server for remote-controlling wireless devices
IEEE Media Management System over SSL (IEEE-MMS-SSL)[95]

Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP), a protocol for communication 
between domain name registries and registrars (RFC 5734)

Link Management Protocol (LMP),[96] a protocol that runs between a pair of 
nodes and is used to manage traffic engineering (TE) links

IRIS[97][98] (Internet Registry Information Service) over BEEP (Blocks 
Extensible Exchange Protocol)[99] (RFC 3983)

Cisco Tag Distribution Protocol[100][101][102]—being replaced by the MPLS Label 
Distribution Protocol[103]

Topology Broadcast based on Reverse-Path Forwarding routing protocol 
(TBRPF; RFC 3684)

Remote HTTPS management for firewall devices running embedded Check Point 
VPN-1 software[112]

Microsoft Remote Web Workplace, a feature of Windows Small Business Server
[113]
Internet Message Access Protocol over TLS/SSL (IMAPS)[10]

Internet Relay Chat over TLS/SSL (IRCS). Previously assigned, but not used 
in common practice.

z/OS Network File System (NFS) (potentially ports 991–1023) 

[78]

[79]

[116][*self-published source*]
